awd_titl_txt: Sustaining and Expanding Mobile Making in Underserved Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project by California State University San Marcos and their collaborators will expand and continue to innovate on a pilot Mobile Making program with the goal of developing a sustainable, regional model for serving underserved, middle-school aged youth in twelve after-school programs in the San Diego region.  Evaluation of the current Mobile Making program has documented positive impacts on participants' interest, self-efficacy, and perception of the relevance of Making/STEM in everyday life, and led to a model for engaging underserved youth in Making. The work will focus on implementing the program model sustainably at greater capacity by increasing the number of undergraduate activity leaders, after-school sites, and level of community engagement. The expanded Mobile Making program is expected to engage ~1800 middle school youth at 12 local school sites, with activities facilitated by ~1020 undergraduate CSU-SM STEM majors. The sites are in ethnically diverse and economically disadvantaged neighborhoods, with as many as 90% of students at some sites qualifying for free or reduced price lunch. The undergraduate facilitators are drawn from CSU-SM's diverse student body, which includes 44% underrepresented minorities. Outcomes are expected to include increases in the youth participants' interest, self-efficacy, and perception of the relevance of Making/STEM in everyday life. Positive impacts on the undergraduate facilitators will include broadened technical skills, increased leadership and 21st century skills, and increased lifelong interest in STEM outreach/informal science education. 

The program is designed to achieve sustainability through innovative means such as involving undergraduate facilitators via Community Service Learning (rather than paid positions), and increased community engagement via development and support of a community of practice including local after-school providers, teachers, Makers, and University members. Evaluation of the program outcomes and lessons learned are expected to result in a comprehensive model for a sustainable, university-based after-school Making program with regional impact in underserved communities. Dissemination to other regions will be leveraged via CSU-SM's membership in the California State University (CSU) system, yielding a potential statewide impact. The support of the CSU Chancellor's Office and input from a CSU implementation group will ensure the applicability of the model to other regional university settings, identify common structural barriers and solutions, and increase the probability of secondary implementations.

This work is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_name: California State University San Marcos Corporation
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SAN MARCOS CORP

por.por_cntn:
The Sustaining and Expanding Mobile Making in Underserved Communities project implemented, evaluated, and disseminated a sustainable, model-based Mobile Making program. Making is inherently interdisciplinary, and most activities cross boundaries between subject areas. The Mobile Making program focuses on STEM making, allowing students to acquire a deeper understanding of physics, computer science, engineering, math, and materials science through their direct experiences with high- and low-tech materials. Mobile Making program is designed around research-based principles for effective out- of-school time (OST) programs.

The Mobile Making program had significant, positive impacts in the underserved communities in the region surrounding California State University San Marcos' (CSU San Marcos). The program reached over 3,000 youth participants during the funding period, the majority of whom are members of underrepresented minority groups. A diverse group of CSU San Marcos students ("STEM Ambassadors") lead weekly, 90-minute activities and serve as near-peer mentors. Ambassadors are important role models and connections to the university for the diverse youth participants, many of whom would be first-generation college students. Over 800 university students have participated during the funding period. 

Mobile Making uses design thinking as a framework to engage K-12 students to solve real-world problems that are personally and socially meaningful to them using low- and high-tech tools such as cardboard, circuity, coding, and robotics. Mobile Making activities are designed using a "modular" approach to lower the barrier for entry and accommodate different levels of participation and commitment from youth participants. Emphasis is placed on projects that use affordable tools and materials that foster a sense of ownership. These projects also allow youth to share their completed projects with family members, which they reported deeply valuing. 

Youth participants reported increased interest in making, self-efficacy, and perception of the relevance of STEM/making in their everyday life because of participation. Further, they reported high levels of agency in executing their making projects, including having ownership of the projects, having control of their work on the projects, and contributing to the design of the maker projects. The undergraduate facilitators' presence was rated, on average, the most critical program component by the youth participants. There were no statistically significant differences between male and female participants with respect to these outcomes. 

Positive impacts on the university student facilitators include broadened technical skills, increased 21st century skills, and increased lifelong interest in STEM outreach/informal science education.

The project resulted in a program model that has been disseminated to other universities in the state of California. The project team worked closely with three other California State University (CSU) campuses (CSU Long Beach, CSU Fresno, and Cal Poly San Luis Obispo) on initial planning for their own Mobile Making programs. The project team developed an ongoing collaboration with the CSU Chancellor's Office to ensure that program and project findings will be disseminated across the CSU system and beyond.


Last Modified: 01/19/2023
Modified by: Edward P Price
